bioghist.p: George A. Q. Miller was stationed in Chicago as Special Postal Agent for the Post Office from 1869 to 1873. Miller devised a scheme of using covered mail wagons as opposed to open drays to minimize postal theft.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of correspondence and clippings related to the postal career of George A. Q. Miller. Materials include a scrapbook of clippings about Miller's idea for using secured covered mail wagons and about civil service awards and other miscellaneous subjects. Miller's commentary is penciled in next to some of the clippings. Correspondence includes letters from Rutherford B. Hayes, James A. Garfield, and John Wanamaker (Postmaster General from 1889-1893), as well as a small batch of letters regarding an unsuccessful attempt to remove Miller from the postal service for drunk and disorderly conduct. The collection also includes a cabinet photograph of George Miller and several pamphlets on civil service reform.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
